title: Cruises Are Back: Here's What You Need to Know About Safety
summary: Major cruise lines are setting sail once more and trying to make a squeaky-clean break from the past. We offer the latest guidance from health experts and look at the big changes onboard and onshore.. AFTER ALMOST 18 dormant months in the age of Covid 19, cruise lines are increasingly beginning to sail again. American Cruise Lines launched from Florida in March. Crystal Cruises resumed operations, with two vessels sailing in the Bahamas, in July. The Norwegian Jade is cruising the Greek Isles, with many Americans on board. At the end of August, Oceania Cruises' Marina set sail from Copenhagen, and its sister ship, the Riviera, is scheduled to travel from Istanbul to Trieste in October. The 2022 itineraries on Viking Ocean Cruises are almost fully booked. Clearly there is demand, and passengers are willing to climb aboard. The question is: Is it safe to cruise now?

title: Unvaccinated People 11 Times as Likely to Die From Covid-19
summary: Hospitalizations and infections were also far higher among the unvaccinated during Delta surge, CDC says. As the Delta variant became dominant in the U.S. this summer, data showed that unvaccinated Americans were 4.6 times as likely to be infected, 10 times as likely to be hospitalized and 11 times as likely to die from Covid-19 than vaccinated people.

title: 5 Ways That 3-D Printers Can Make You Cooler
summary: The revolutionary machines can make your life easier and help you impress your friends (and kids). Skeptical? Read on.... AS REVOLUTIONARY technologies evolve, they shrink-once taking up entire rooms, they eventually fit on your kitchen counter. 3-D printers have made it to that stage. And at around $300 for high-tech machines, they're now affordable enough that almost anyone can have a go. If you still view them as irredeemably nerdy, it's time to rethink.

title: Jasper Johns's Lifetime of Making and Breaking Rules
summary: At 91, the American painter is the subject of a new retrospective spanning museums in two cities. Jasper Johns has been one of America's most famous artists since the 1950s, when he began to make his highly distinctive paintings of everyday images like flags. Those early works remain his best-known, but a new retrospective opening Sept. 29 shows that Mr. Johns, 91, has never stopped exploring new directions. It's a testimony to his long, productive career that "Jasper Johns: Mind/Mirror" needs two museums-the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and the Philadelphia Museum of Art-to display approximately 550 artworks spanning seven decades.

title: Apple's Next iPhone Is Coming Soon. Here's What to Expect.

And even if you aren't interested in the latest and greatest, the company generally drops the price of some older models along with the new crop.

title: Interior Designers on the 7 Most Comfortable Chairs to Buy
summary: Seven seats waiting to give you a great big hug, as recommended by design pros who've done more than their share of sinking into furniture. WHILE WE anxiously wait to resume regular programming, comfort has become a high priority on the home front. With that in mind, we asked scores of interior designers to name the most sink-into-able chairs available today. Two respondents enthusiastically backed the Song Armchair from 3-year-old British company Maker&Son. New York designer Ghislaine Viñas called it "freakishly and deliciously comfortable...[it makes] you want to immediately curl up and snuggle." Who among us wouldn't welcome a hug from a chair these days? Here, six more designer-recommended seats waiting to embrace you.

title: Construction of Nord Stream 2 Pipeline Is Complete, Russian Gas Company Says
summary: Biden administration has maintained public opposition to pipeline but also removed obstacles to its completion. Russia's gas-export monopoly said Friday that construction had been completed on a controversial pipeline to Europe, marking the end of a multiyear geopolitical struggle that has strained U.S.-German relations and served as a test of U.S. resolve amid heightened tensions with the Kremlin.

title: Afghan Female Orchestra's Escape Halted 100 Yards From Freedom
summary: U.S. effort to help members of Zohra flee were thwarted when Taliban guards refused to wake a commander at Kabul's airport. Members of an internationally renowned orchestra of Afghan women and girls remain stuck in Afghanistan after an attempt to get them out through Kabul's airport in the last days of the U.S. war failed.

title: The War on Terror Shifts to 'Brainistan'
summary: The West needs a better system for identifying radical Islamists and cutting out the religious underpinnings of jihad.. Twenty years ago, 19 of my fellow Arab Muslims carried out the worst foreign attack on American soil in history. Slipping into the country legally and apparently without raising alarm bells among our intelligence and law-enforcement communities, these members of al Qaeda, a radical Islamist group bent on jihad, crashed two commercial airliners into New York's World Trade Center towers and a third plane into the Pentagon. They failed with a fourth aircraft because of the actions of courageous and selfless passengers. As a result, nearly 3,000 people were murdered that day, and many more have succumbed to related injuries in the ensuing years.

title: How The Wall Street Journal Published on 9/11
summary: The newsroom was destroyed and the staff scattered, but the paper came out on schedule.. It will happen again. Though few of us want to admit it, the 9/11 terrorist attacks are destined to be repeated, probably amplified, at some point. There is no scale to measure the degree of human suffering that follows such events. We can't change history or prevent the inevitable sequels. But we can remind ourselves that there will also be a morning after, when the families of those who perished and the shaken survivors begin to pick themselves up and look to the future as a means of rebuffing those who seek to harm us.

title: Hearing Too Much in a Noisy World
summary: Even ordinary levels of background din can drown out the meaning our brains seek from sound. When the pandemic struck in March of 2020, the human world went quiet. During what some are now calling the anthropause, highways and byways emptied of cars while shops and services locked their doors for weeks and months. Using sensitive sound level analyzers, scientists from every continent confirmed a reduction in human-created sound levels, in some cities by as much as seven decibels, which translates to about one-fifth as loud as before.

title: Biden Boosts Vaccine Requirements for Large Employers, Federal Workers to Combat Covid-19
summary: Department of Labor plans to issue an emergency temporary standard implementing the new requirement. All employers with 100 or more employees would have to require that their workers be vaccinated or undergo at least weekly Covid-19 testing under a new plan announced by President Biden to curb the spread of the pandemic.

title: Kroger Had a Spill in Aisle Five
summary: After an impressive run, supermarket chain's shares dropped after missing bottom line expectations. Supermarkets were late bloomers among the Covid-19 winners, unrecognized last year during the pandemic boom but finally gaining steam this year. Kroger 's results Friday seriously disrupted that rally.

title: The Fantastic U.S. Open Final That No One Saw Coming
summary: Teenagers Leylah Fernandez and Emma Raducanu meet Saturday in their first-ever major tournament championship-and that's just the start of the history. They'll laugh with amazement about this madness one day. Wait: They're probably laughing about it now. How can they not?

title: Elizabeth Holmes's Trial Attire-Yes to Diaper Bags, No to Turtlenecks
summary: The former Theranos CEO has adopted a soft new look-which diverges from her previous black-turtleneck uniform-as a defendant in her criminal trial. IN 2014 AND 2015, Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes appeared on the covers of Fortune, Forbes, Inc., T: The New York Times Style Magazine, Bloomberg Businessweek and Glamour. The photographs on these magazine covers are almost identical. On each, she wears her signature black turtleneck, inspired by her late idol Steve Jobs, who'd long favored a version by designer Issey Miyake. Her blonde hair is in a chignon, and her gaze is steady. Ms. Holmes's look was so recognizable that it's still a popular Halloween costume, and it has even spawned ironic merch with her visage on it. (One T-shirt says, "Fake it 'till you make it.")

title: Democrats Float Taxes on Partnerships, Buybacks
summary: Senators give details on two proposals that could generate money, as support for a major capital-gains tax increase wanes. WASHINGTON-Senate Democrats offered proposals Friday for tighter tax rules on partnerships and an excise tax on stock buybacks, as lawmakers look to plug gaps in their fast-moving, $3.5 trillion healthcare, education and climate legislation.

title: The Images of President Biden That Will Linger
summary: Remember his angry, challenging look as he deflected responsibility?. Peggy Noonan's "The Afghan Fiasco Will Stick to Biden" (Declarations, Sept. 4) is one of her better columns, accompanied by a photo of President Biden, head bent in apparent anguish. But the image I remember from the speech is Mr. Biden's angry, challenging look as he deflected responsibility and even found a victory in the retreat. I nearly visualized former President Trump standing with him, denying the election results and claiming victory. Are we no longer able to find great leaders when we most need them?

title: What Do Colleges Owe Vaccinated Students?
summary: The president of Amherst responds on Covid rules.. Leslie Bienen's op-ed "Colleges Violate Their Promises to Vaccinated Students" (Sept. 4) does not mention the serious spread of Covid-19 that other colleges and universities are already experiencing. These institutions have a responsibility to keep their communities as safe as possible from a highly contagious and virulent variant.

title: Grocery Store CEO Wants More Food Stamps
summary: SNAP behaves precisely like a social-support network should.. Many conservatives feel, as your editorial "The Democratic Food-Stamp Boom" (Aug. 18) argues, that this is an attempt by liberals to increase the deficit for a program that creates dependency without addressing the root cause.

title: Maybe Gavin Newsom Wants More Homeless on the Street
summary: His program to reduce homelessness includes the same policies most people would implement to increase it.. Regarding Stephen Eide's "Homelessness Is Behind the Anger at Gavin Newsom" (Cross Country, Sept. 4): Assume you have the power to change laws and culture, and your goal is to increase the number of people living on the streets. What would you change? I've been asking people for several years. Here are the most common answers:

title: Two World Trade Center War Trophies Left for the Taliban
summary: The new Afghan regime could use them to celebrate 9/11.. Regarding Daniel Henninger's "9/11 Did Not Change Everything" (Wonder Land, Sept. 9): Sept. 11, 2021, marks the 20th anniversary of what can be described as America's second day of infamy. The numbers killed, wounded and forever scarred by the al Qaeda terrorist attacks were even larger than those of America's first day of infamy, the attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: Men's Face-lifts: Once Taboo, Now Trendy (and Professionally Strategic)
summary: There's no shame in being vain-just ask newly taut designer Marc Jacobs. Why men ranging from C-suite executives to Hollywood stars are increasingly going under the knife.. AS ONE OF America's arbiters of cool, fashion designer Marc Jacobs has been the face of many trends. But this July, when the perennial enfant terrible, now 58, revealed in a gleeful Instagram post that he'd had a face-lift, just one day into his postoperative recovery, his newly taut mug became the story.

title: 'Travels With George' Review: A President Hits the Road
summary: How better to learn about a new nation than to travel through it? A historian follows George Washington's get-to-know-you tour.. However Americans felt on the eve of the 1960 presidential election, they largely refused to share their political opinions with the novelist John Steinbeck as he drove across the country with the poodle he immortalized in "Travels With Charley" (1962). At one point, Steinbeck wondered if his countrymen were, as he put it, "scared to have an opinion."

title: Hard-Hit Industries Renew Calls for Covid-19 Aid
summary: Prospects for additional financial assistance face uphill climb as Congress weighs several large priorities. WASHINGTON-Restaurants, live-events businesses and gyms are among industries renewing calls for Congress to provide additional financial assistance amid signs the rise in Covid-19 cases is slowing U.S. economic activity.

title: 'Water' Review: The Ebb and Flow of History
summary: States are keen on controlling the most vital substance on earth. Water has other plans.. The trouble with water, Giulio Boccaletti reminds us in his sweeping "Water: A Biography," is that it moves. Rivers flood; rain clouds drift away; oceans rise. When human beings lived as nomadic hunter-gatherers, we adapted by migrating toward dry ground or fresh sources of water. But once we settled into permanent farming communities some 10,000 years ago, our options narrowed and our relationship with water became more fraught.

title: 'What's Eating the Universe?' Review: A Pocket Guide to the Cosmos
summary: A whirlwind tour through the vastness of space and the innermost recesses of subatomic matter.. As the pandemic ebbed and flowed this summer, we watched the spectacle of billionaires racing to the edge of space. Shortly after reaching an altitude of 53 miles in his rocket plane, Richard Branson heralded "the dawn of a new space age," while Jeff Bezos-who flew more than 10 miles higher nine days later-said he wanted to "build a road to space so our kids, and their kids, can build the future." While Mr. Branson dreams of an orbiting hotel, Mr. Bezos of a base on the moon and Elon Musk a colony on Mars, the physicist Paul Davies explores a far wider canvas in his introduction to cosmology, "What's Eating the Universe?" This "scientific detective story," Mr. Davies tells us, travels "from the very edge of time itself, through our own epoch, into the infinite future" and weaves together "the vastness of space with the innermost recesses of subatomic matter."

title: Florida Teens Charged in School Shooting Plot
summary: Students had studied 1999 Columbine massacre extensively, authorities say. Authorities averted a potential shooting at a middle school in Lee County, Fla., after arresting two students who were allegedly plotting an attack.

title: Sick Day for Biotech Stocks Won't Last
summary: Tough talk from the Biden Administration on drug prices and weak sales have harmed biotech stocks, but these symptoms likely won't last. This week, just about everything that could go wrong for the sector did.

title: Helene An Reinvented Vietnamese Food in the U.S.
summary: At 77, the 'mother of fusion cuisine' is guiding her family's business through the challenges of the pandemic. When Saigon fell at the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, Helene An's family fled the country with nothing but the clothes on their backs. At 31, Ms. An found herself living in a one-bedroom apartment in San Francisco with her in-laws, husband and three daughters, trying to make a life in a new world. She spent her days working as an accountant, teaching French and math, and studying English, and her nights helping her mother-in-law run a small Italian cafe. "We were struggling to survive," she says.

title: Brian Robbins Expected to Take Over Leadership of Paramount Movie Studio
summary: Mr. Robbins, head of Nickelodeon, will replace Jim Gianopulos, as ViacomCBS aims to beef up original content on Paramount+. Brian Robbins, the head of ViacomCBS Inc.'s Nickelodeon kids TV empire, is expected to take over as chairman and chief executive of the company's Paramount Pictures movie studio, according to people familiar with the matter.

summary: Conference presidents voted Friday to add BYU, Cincinnati, Houston and UCF to bolster its membership once Oklahoma and Texas move to the SEC. Facing fears that it is getting smaller, the Big 12 is about to get bigger.

title: Lebanon Gets New Government After 13-Month Deadlock

BEIRUT-Lebanon's political factions agreed Friday on a new government led by former Prime Minister Najib Mikati, ending a more than yearlong deadlock as the country struggles with an economic collapse that has pushed millions into poverty.

title: Will Trumpism Dominate the GOP Future-and Will Trump?
summary: Next year's midterm elections should reveal how the former president's efforts are affecting the fate of the Republican Party, his rivals, and his own aspirations. All assert a grievous harm being done to America by Democrats and President Biden-and all plead urgently for contributions to the Trump political organization.

title: Ford to Close Plants in India, a Tough Market for Auto Giants
summary: U.S. car maker accumulated more than $2 billion in losses in a country that prefers budget-friendly vehicles. Ford Motor Co. title: 'Here in Our Auschwitz and Other Stories' Review: The Terrible Truth
summary: Borowski's stories, informed by his time in Nazi concentration camps, are told in an icy style that cloaks hot rage.. "A book must be the ax for the frozen sea inside us," said Franz Kafka. "Here in Our Auschwitz and Other Stories," the fullest English-language collection to date of Tadeusz Borowski's prose, is such a book. Borowski's sharp-edged descriptions of life in Nazi concentration camps shatter the limits of even Kafka's most surreal imaginings.

title: Bank of America Overhauls Top Management Ranks
summary: Bank names new CFO and adds three women to its senior ranks in biggest leadership reshuffling in more than a decade. Bank of America Corp. said Friday it is shaking up its top leadership team, installing new finance, technology and legal chiefs and adding three women to its senior ranks.

title: 'Mortal Kombat' Can Teach China a Thing or Two About Videogames
summary: From 'penny dreadfuls' to comic books to music, often the best way to make a business boom has been to try limiting it. Back in Business is an occasional column that puts the present day in perspective by looking at business history and those who shaped it. Read previous installments of the column here.

title: WhatsApp to Offer Encryption on Cloud Backups
summary: Facebook messaging unit's protection feature is the latest development in fight over encryption technology. Facebook Inc.'s WhatsApp on Friday said it would extend encryption on the messaging service to backups of chats shared on the platform when they are stored on Apple Inc. and Google's cloud services.

title: Children's Books: The Joy of a Little Scare
summary: Alarming creatures and ghostly forms abound in these spine-tingling books.. For Rod Serling, the medium was television; for Shirley Jackson, it was short-form fiction; both storytellers were adept at giving adults the heebie-jeebies by situating sinister tales in bland and ordinary places. Josh Allen partakes of this fine American tradition with "Only If You Dare," a collection of 13 creepy stories for middle-schoolers.

title: UPS to Buy Delivery Platform Roadie
summary: Deal thrusts UPS into same-day delivery market; Roadie has network of 200,000 crowdsourced drivers. United Parcel Service Inc. is getting into same-day delivery with a deal to buy Roadie Inc., a platform that uses gig workers to deliver items from retailers and other shippers quickly.

title: Fiction: Joy Williams's 'Harrow' Review
summary: In the blighted world of Joy Williams's novel, the survivors of a global environmental crisis aren't chastened but indignant.. The unexamined assumption of most apocalypse fiction-surely the century's fastest growing literary genre-is that catastrophe will bring about repentance, or at least a modicum of reflection. But "Harrow," by Joy Williams, isn't having it. In the novel's ravaged "post-disaster present," the survivors of a global environmental collapse aren't chastened, only indignant. "People think the planet is attempting to make threats-the withdrawal of spring-and nonnegotiable demands, and it pisses them off," reports one character, and as part of the punitive, hardline response to Mother Nature's intransigence, "all that is non-human is considered detrimental to the future." The ridiculous, pigheaded, bemused, endlessly distracted and continuously self-sabotaging state of the future is the subject of this wonderfully goading satire.

title: Taliban Allow Women in Universities, but Fear Keeps Most at Home
summary: Resume Subscription. KABUL-Women account for some 60% of the 2,400 students enrolled at Kabul's Ghalib University, one of many private colleges that sprang up in Afghanistan over the past two decades. When it reopened this week under new Taliban rules, with women and men instructed to attend on alternate days, only 21 female students showed up.

title: Here's Why Covid-19 Shots Don't Last a Lifetime

title: Five Best: Books on Dogs
summary: Selected by Rick Bragg, the author, most recently, of 'The Speckled Beauty: A Dog and His People.'. By Willie Morris (1995)

title: Two by Stanisław Lem: The Man Who Saw Tomorrow
summary: Stanisław Lem's works of short fiction were laboratories in which various futures were put to the test.. The Polish Parliament has declared 2021 the "Stanisław Lem Year." Its slogan, "I've seen the future," might aptly apply to many science-fiction writers. But the visions of Stanisław Lem (1921-2006) are still unknown to most American readers.

title: 'Pump' Review: The Pulse of Life
summary: The complex operation of your most important muscle has been fine-tuned by nature.. In April 2014, nine blue whales perished off the shores of Newfoundland after getting trapped in the ice packs of the Cabot Strait. One of these leviathans, measuring 76 feet long, eventually turned up in the frigid waters of the tiny outport of Rocky Harbour. A team from the Royal Ontario Museum arrived to salvage its organs. (Studies of the gross anatomy of the whale are often thwarted by the speedy putrefaction and spontaneous explosion of beached specimens.) They succeeded in extracting the heart, which was underwhelming in appearance. As Bill Schutt observes in his fascinating "Pump," it looked like "a four-hundred-pound flesh-colored soup dumpling." While still massive, it was smaller than expected, closer in size to a golf cart than a Cadillac. Its podgy appearance belied its superb adaptation to the demands of its bathypelagic environment. Unlike the rigid human heart, the heart of the blue whale is an amorphous bag of muscle, able to shrink and still pump blood under the immense pressures of the ocean depths.

title: 'Two-Way Mirror' Review: The Poet Persevered
summary: Elizabeth Barrett Browning fought illness and prejudice in pursuit of her lifelong dream: to be read.. How, and why, do readers love Elizabeth Barrett Browning? A popular poet with an international following, a progressive thinker about women's roles, children's rights and slavery; a formal pioneer who wrote, of all things, a bestselling verse-novel-Barrett Browning has endured a checkered literary afterlife. Cultural commentators, rather than contemplate her achievements, often emphasize, if not exaggerate, her personal experience: her long illness, her tyrannical father and her love affair with fellow poet Robert Browning. In "Two-Way Mirror," her biography of the poet, Fiona Sampson spins an intriguingly complex account of her subject. The volume, the first biography of Barrett Browning (1806-1861) in more than 30 years, draws energy from the drama of her experience even as it reveals her intelligence, perseverance and power.

title: Hong Kong's Financial Ties to China Deepen as Wealth Link Launches
summary: Cross-border investment program for individuals is part of Xi Jinping's plans to more closely integrate Greater Bay Area region. Hong Kong and mainland China took a step toward even greater financial integration, with the start of a cross-border investment program for individuals known as "Wealth Management Connect."

title: People Want to Work From Anywhere and Keep Their Big-City Salaries
summary: Most Popular News. David Pedersen decided this summer that he wanted to move to Denver from Seattle, continuing to perform his tech-company job remotely from his new city. His primary concern: Would the shift require a pay cut?

title: German Immigrant Managed Marlboro Cash Flow
summary: Hans Storr, who has died at age 89, rose to chief financial officer at cigarette maker Philip Morris and lined up financing for major acquisitions. Hans Storr, seeking work after finishing school in his native West Germany in the early 1950s, decided to see whether the U.S. military forces based in his shattered country might have any openings. At a U.S. base in Baumholder, he impressed recruiters with his ability to speak English and French.

title: Rehab Hospital CEO Blended Research Into Therapy
summary: Joanne C. Smith, who died at age 60, led an innovative institution in Chicago that attracts patients from around the world. As a medical student in 1987, Joanne C. Smith met a teenage girl with spina bifida whose legs had been amputated. The girl had taught herself to walk on her hands. Then, in an attempt to make her look more normal, doctors gave her wooden legs and belted her into a wheelchair.

title: Centrist House Democrats Offer Rival Prescription Drug Price Bill
summary: Party lawmakers seek to close divisions on $3.5 trillion social welfare and climate package. WASHINGTON-A pair of centrist House Democrats are expected to soon release their own proposal for lowering the cost of prescription-drug prices, as the party tries to close internal divisions over a popular plank of its $3.5 trillion social welfare and climate package.

title: 'Tattleware': From Childish Chatter to Sinister Supervision
summary: Surreptitious software designed to monitor employees gets its name from medieval Flemish and a tale about a fox. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: Treasury Could Hit Debt Ceiling Deadline by Mid-October, Analysts Say
summary: Uncertainty looms over when and how Congress will address the debt limit. WASHINGTON-The government will likely run out of cash and could begin to miss payments on its obligations some time between mid-October and mid-November, according to a new projection from the Bipartisan Policy Center, a Washington think tank.

title: How to Prepare Your Finances Before Quitting Your Job
summary: The 'Great Resignation' is on. Here's what to do about your finances before embarking on the slowdown you've been craving.. Nearly two years into working from home, some young professionals have reached a crucial decision point. Rather than scale the career ladder in search of higher salaries, financial advisers say these workers want work-life balance, giving priority to family time and personal life.

title: What's Happening in Afghanistan?
summary: Taliban consolidate control 20 years after American troops first landed. The Taliban declared the restoration of their Islamic Emirate, days before the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks that sparked the U.S. invasion in Afghanistan. The new government places core hard-line leaders in top positions and excludes women and members of the Shiite minority, belying its earlier assurances that it would be representative of all Afghans.

title: Infrastructure Bill Could Jump-Start Electric School Bus Business
summary: The $1 trillion bill looks to be a boon for school districts that want clean-energy vehicles-and bus companies that supply them. The $1 trillion infrastructure bill working through Congress stands to be a boon for school districts looking to buy clean-energy vehicles-and the bus companies that supply them.

title: Wells Fargo, Zscaler, Dave & Buster's: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures suggest Wall Street indexes could break a losing streak. U.S. stock futures rose, suggesting major indexes may open with muted gains at the end of a choppy week on Wall Street. Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's open.

title: Hurricane Ida's Destruction Adds to Car Market's Woes
summary: The storm damaged vehicles across several states, sending shoppers to dealers already struggling because of the chip shortage. The flooding damage wrought by Hurricane Ida last week is expected to send car owners back to dealerships to replace vehicles. The timing couldn't be worse.

title: These Cult Vinegars Make Everything Taste Better-Instantly
summary: A new wave of slow-brewed craft vinegars from makers like Tart and Acid League deliver complex, concentrated flavor and tremendous verve to cooking and cocktails. A guide to the best bottles to buy and how to use them.. SCOTT FRIEDMANN had no intention of starting a vinegar company. The plastic vats filled with liquid in various stages of fermentation that were stinking up his basement were intended as a hobby project for Mr. Friedmann and his then-15-year-old son. They started with red and white wines but soon moved on to aged hard cider, oranges, Campari and fresh flowers grown on the family's farm outside Toronto.

title: Journalism Schools Leave Graduates With Hefty Student Loans
summary: Resume Subscription. News reporting has lost thousands of jobs over the past decade, with a further slide predicted. Yet, journalism schools continue to churn out heavily indebted master's degree graduates hoping to find a footing in the cratering industry.

title: Growing Use of Cryptocurrency in Afghanistan Poses Security Concerns
summary: If the Taliban were to adopt cryptocurrency as part of a national economic policy, it could aid efforts to circumvent sanctions. The Taliban takeover of Afghanistan has fueled a surge in the use of cryptocurrency as Afghans grasp for ways to cope with a deepening financial crisis, market analysts and local traders say, a trend that may offer hope for an ailing economy, but that poses concerns for Western security officials.

title: Switzerland Gives Green Light to Crypto Trading Exchange
summary: Stock exchange SIX's digital arm SDX will let investors, via regulated institutions, trade, settle and store digital tokens. Switzerland cleared the way Friday for more trading of bitcoin and other digital assets in the country by authorizing a new digital stock exchange.

title: Why Deshaun Watson Isn't Playing or Hasn't Been Traded
summary: The star quarterback faces allegations of wrongdoing and also wants a trade-putting the team at an impasse and placing him on the sidelines. When the Houston Texans season begins on Sunday, the team's most important player, quarterback Deshaun Watson, will be absent from the field. The reason involves two unrelated and unresolved events between the end of last season and the beginning of this one, which have combined to place Watson and his team in a stalemate.

title: No Level-Up for Chinese Game Companies Yet
summary: Report of a full stop on game approvals-later corrected-punished Chinese game shares. It still looks early to buy the dip, however.. The latest regulatory news punishing Chinese game shares looks like a bit of a tempest in a teacup. Investors would be wise to keep the hatches firmly battened down anyway.

title: The Wrong Way to Target Corporate Excess
summary: Stock buybacks and lavish executive pay make easy targets for raising more tax revenue, but some proposals to curb them would create more problems than they solve. When in doubt, go after corporate fat cats.

title: Virus Variants Mu and Lambda Unlikely to Supplant Delta
summary: Delta's highly infectious nature positions it to outcompete new variants, scientists say. The Delta variant of the Covid-19 virus appears well positioned to maintain its dominance over new variants such as Lambda and Mu, virologists say.

title: Bitcoin Fans Borrow to Buy Homes, Cars-and More Crypto
summary: Resume Subscription. Michael Anderson mined bitcoin in his dorm room and left a corporate job to invest in cryptocurrency projects. When he bought his first home in San Francisco this year, he didn't turn to a bank. Instead, he borrowed against his cryptocurrency.

title: U.S. Treasury to Finish Sanctions Policy Review This Fall
summary: Human rights and humanitarian groups are increasingly concerned about the pace of the review. The Biden administration expects to complete its ongoing sanctions policy review this fall, a U.S. Treasury Department spokeswoman said, as some human rights and humanitarian groups express concern about how long the review is taking and the level of engagement with nongovernmental organizations.

title: Fed Prepares for November Reduction in Bond Buying
summary: Phasing out the Fed's pandemic-era stimulus by the middle of 2022 could clear the path for an interest-rate increase. Federal Reserve officials will seek to forge agreement at their coming meeting to begin scaling back their easy money policies in November.

title: Cost Inflation Blows Through the Wind Turbine Industry
summary: Covid delays and expensive shipping will likely hurt more than higher prices for steel and other raw materials. Wind turbine makers have lost some of the wind in their sails this year. Investors can blame Covid delays, rising commodity prices, and a likely lull in orders after a frantic 2020.

summary: Firsthand accounts and commentary on the attacks from the Sept. 12, 2001 edition of the paper.. By Daniel Henninger

title: Italy Tries to Fix a Chronic Problem: Slow Courts
summary: Draghi's government is pushing through overhauls to speed up slow judicial proceedings that have weighed on Italy's economy for years. ROME-In 2009, Italian prosecutors began investigating Bank of America Merrill Lynch and one of its employees after a regional authority suffered losses on a derivative contract it had signed with the bank.

title: Biden, China's Xi Jinping Hold First Call in Months
summary: The American president initiated the call as recent high-level U.S.-China meetings have been unproductive, U.S. officials say. WASHINGTON-President Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping spoke by phone Thursday night in an effort to ease hostilities between the two powers and reset lines of communication after recent high-level meetings were described by U.S. officials as unproductive.

title: Tencent-Backed Tech Giant Sea Taps Investors for $6 Billion
summary: Sea says some of the proceeds would help expand its business, while funds could also be deployed on investments and acquisitions. Southeast Asia's most valuable listed company, Sea Ltd. , is raising at least $6 billion in new funds, capitalizing on investor enthusiasm for the region's fast-growing technology industry.

title: Grubhub, DoorDash, Uber Eats Sue New York City Over Fee Caps
summary: Food-delivery companies say cap sets a dangerous precedent. DoorDash Inc., Grubhub Inc. and Uber Technologies Inc.'s Eats division are suing New York City over its law permanently capping the amount of commissions the apps can charge restaurants to use their services, the latest move in a growing clash between the platforms and local regulators.

title: Giuliani Associate Pleads Guilty in Campaign-Donation Scheme
summary: Businessman was key figure in first impeachment of former President Donald Trump. A former associate of Rudy Giuliani pleaded guilty to solicitation of a political contribution by a foreign national on Friday, nearly two years after he and his business partners emerged as key figures in the impeachment inquiry into former President Donald Trump.

title: Photos That Defined 9/11, and the People in Them-20 Years Later
summary: Resume Subscription. Thousands of photographs captured the shock, horror, heroism and humanity brought on by Sept. 11. Now, 20 years after the terrorist attacks, survivors and witnesses who appeared in some of the most compelling images told The Wall Street Journal their stories and what has happened to them in the years since.

title: How 9/11 Hastened Downtown New York's Transformation
summary: Resume Subscription. When the Twin Towers collapsed on Sept. 11, 2001, the tremors shook a bar four blocks away. The proprietor of Jim Brady's Bar and Restaurant says it felt like an earthquake. More than 20 of his regulars died that day in the World Trade Center, and the pub was closed for weeks.

title: EPA Moves for Permanent Block on Pebble Mine Project in Alaska
summary: Biden administration proposed Clean Water Act protections across Bristol Bay. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is proposing sweeping environmental protections for Bristol Bay in southwest Alaska, a plan that could permanently block the development of the controversial Pebble Mine copper-and-gold project.

title: Theranos Trial Paused Over Possible Covid-19 Exposure
summary: Judge cancels Friday court proceedings amid concerns. Just days into Theranos Inc. founder Elizabeth Holmes's criminal-fraud trial, issues have come up with three jurors in the case, raising concern from the federal judge overseeing what's expected to be a more than three-month-long trial.

title: TSA Doubles Fines for Travelers Who Won't Wear Masks
summary: Move is part of the Biden administration's new plan to combat Covid-19. President Biden is strengthening penalties for mask scofflaws on planes, buses and trains as part of his administration's new plan to combat Covid-19.

title: Two Fed Chiefs to Sell Stocks to Avoid Appearance of Conflict of Interest
summary: Robert Kaplan and Eric Rosengren defended their investment decisions as consistent with their respective bank's code of conduct policies. The leaders of the Boston and Dallas Federal Reserve Banks said they would sell off individual stocks they own, invest the proceeds in diversified indexed funds or cash savings and cease trading in individual securities.
